Total setup for me was done in about 10 mins.I dislike that the paper tray pushes out the back of the printer as pictured, but itâ€™s easy to live with.For a quality budget printer, I give this 5 stars.

title: Fair Printer For Cost
body: I am fairly tech savvy which saved me on this printer. This is a good printer if you simply want an inexpensive printer that prints black and white well. The print quality is good and the wireless capabilities work well. If I could review it based on that alone, it would be a 5 star inexpensive printer. It does have duplex (double sided printing) though it did take me some time to figure this out. Once I figured it out, it is a nice feature.But, and this is a big one, the set up for a non tech savvy person depends all on interpreting the photo on the enclosed insert. There are no written instructions. I was able to figure out how to set this up to my wireless network just by plugging it in and following the prompts on the printer screen. I didn't think it was difficult but it definitely takes someone who would think of it instead of relying on directions. There are plugs to connect it directly to a computer but I wanted this for the wireless capability.The size of the printer is a little big for the lack of other functions and I wish the cord were just a tad longer so it would reach the plug I use in my printing area. One other issue for me is that the print cartridges for this printer seem expensive for a cheaper printer.One more odd thing worth mentioning is that the tray does extend (though hard to find) but even for regular size letter paper, it pushes open the back cover tray cover. Not really an issue for me, it's just not something I've noticed.If you're fairly tech savvy and need an inexpensive printer for monochrome printing, this really isn't bad. However, if you aren't tech savvy and can't figure out set up without written instructions, look elsewhere or look for a video or instructions online.Pros:** Print Quality** Wireless Capability** Duplex Printing** Good Print SpeedCons ** Size ** Set up** Cord Length** Tray opens back cover for regular size paper** Ink Replacement Cost

title: Simple to set up
body: This printer was easy to set up for our household. We connected the printer direct to our Win 7 desktop PC and the computer detected the printer immediately and automatically loaded the software drivers to make it run. We then connected our Win 8 and Win 10 laptops to it thru the wireless connections following the directions that came with the printer... and after a reboot on the laptops, the printer was available. It is fairly simple to do if you follow the directions.This is a nice printer for a family that does not print very often. We would buy the expensive ink carts for our bubble jet printer and they would dry out and plug jets. Then we would buy more ink carts and spend hours trying to get the plugged jets to function good enough for a print job and then have the whole process repeat again. The ink jet printers were way, way too much maintenance for us. This laser printer won't have ANY of those issues!!! Very happy!My neighbor has a similar Lexmark printer that is 6 years old and he hasn't had any issues with it. He has been buying generic toner carts at a fraction of the cost of OEM toner carts, and they work well.If you don't need super fast office printer speed, then this is a good printer for home or a small business.

title: Great value, fast printing, and good quality in one package.
body: Â Everything is straightforward on this black and white toner cartridge printer. Where I ran into issues is forgetting that the cartridge had security tapes on it that needed to be removed and nowhere was there any information that the security tape was on the cartridge and needed to be removed.So when I had got to the last step to print a calibration page, it was giving me a setup error. Got that done and everything worked fine after that.As for the setup. Because you have only a small toggle and display, it will be pretty difficult to navigate through to connecting to your network and then putting in your password. Fortunately for me, for this printer, the Wifi network it was going on had a numeric password so it was not that bad. But it was like having to use your tv remote to put in the numbers and toggle through every alphabet per numeric sequence. So you can imagine this part taking longer than it needs to.It did ask me if I wanted to do mobile setup. So maybe that would have prevented this cumbersome setup method.But once I got it connected to the network, all the other computers were able to connect to it.The print quality is great. And it prints fast.For the price and quality, I consider this to be a great value. Years of good use are expected from this Lexmark monochrome printer.

title: Great Printer. Don't Use Recommended Plug In App.
body: This printer is great, once you can get it to work.The set up was difficult due to the terrible "Lexmark Assistant App" that they recommend to use. It wouldn't work properly and we had to set it up through the printer itself.Then they recommend downloading the "Lexmark Plug In" app. This would only allow us to print 'pdf' files and nothing else. Any other document would give us an error.We were beginning to think something was wrong with the printer, but it was just the terrible Lexmark apps, because my husband dowloaded a third party "Plug In" app that claimed to be able to print wirelessly from all types of printers and this app worked fine.Once we weren't using Lexmark's apps the printer worked great.It prints quickly and clearly. It isn't very loud either.It's a shame that their recommended apps are so bad because the printer is a a good printer.I almost deducted another star because of the terrible apps, but that didn't seem fair because the printer is good.

title: Many pluses from size and price to print quality and speed
body: The printer comes with an installation cd but no printed information. This leads to some confusion. The cd installs scanner software, but the printer is not a scanner. There is a power button in front which lights up white but, in order to print you need an unlabeled blue light to be lit and the power light in front to be off. For the blue light to come on you need to press the OK button, the power light turns off, and â€œReadyâ€ appears on the digital display. Granted, itâ€™s not hard to learn, but itâ€™s hardly intuitive or logical. On the website, I read that it has an â€˜activeâ€™ and a â€˜sleepâ€™ mode.â€™ Maybe this is an explanation for the weird light situation.There is also a slight confusion in the process of setting up the paper tray. There is a rather stiff blue spring control that you need to press (hard) to take it to letter size (or legal or A4). Once you get past that, itâ€™s uphill from there. The printing quality and speed are great. The ease of printing two-sided is also a great plus. In addition to the paper tray which pulls out from the bottom and holds an impressive amount of paper, there is an additional tray for manual feeding in case you need to print an envelope or a different size of paper than what you have loaded on the tray. When youâ€™re on the printing dialog, just select page setup and you get to select which tray you want. If you donâ€™t select page setup the default is to feed paper from the main tray.All in all, itâ€™s a great little printer. It fits anywhere; it prints fast and sharp; one toner will yield about 6,000 pages; and it will work as a wireless printer or connected via USB from your computer or phone or other device. On the whole, itâ€™s a solid performer at a reasonable price.

title: Great printer but difficult install
body: The Lexmark B2236 printer is a 'budget' monochrome laser printer. It can connect with wired Ethernet, wireless, or USB. It can print one-sided or duplex (both sides of a page). My overall rating is 3-1/2 stars because of the Cons listed below. If Lexmark fixes those or even some, I would give this printer 5 stars.Setup:After removing all the tape that holds things together for shipping, you'll pull the toner cartridge - along with the drum - out of the front panel and remove both the paper protecting the drum and the activating strip from the toner cartridge. Put them back then plug in the cord and use the display to set region, date, and time. Now you need to install the driver from the included disc.I installed the driver from the disc, but the setup software could not detect the printer on my network (wireless). I went into setup on the printer and connected it to my wireless network. This can take a bit of time as you have to scroll through the alphabet for each character of your network password.Afterward, I went to the install screen on my computer and installed the printer using the IP address. Now it works. Put paper in the tray. You have to move the dividers around before you paper will fit. And, oddly, the tray protrudes from the back of the printer with letter size paper.Printing:I printed a two page Word document using duplex printing. The printer is very fast and automatically reverses the page to print the back side. The printer defaults to duplex printing which is probably not your default preference. You'll have to select single side printing in Printer Setup in your program and you'll have to do this for each different document. Anyone know how to set single side printing as default? Setting it in the printer configuration via the IP address does nothing.Whenever I send a document to the printer, a popup appears telling me the SMTP server is not setup. The document prints anyway.The print quality is excellent. Fonts are crisp and clean. While not photo quality, pictures are still very detailed with very good tonal range.I was able to print a document from my phone using Lexmark Mobile App.Miscellaneous:I had to search Lexmark's website for the user manual. I couldn't find it on the disc.Pro:Very fastDuplex printingCrisp textVery good tonal range on imagesCon:Difficult to setupPaper tray protrudes from the backHigh yield toner cartridge is about the same price as the printer.Envelope printing wrinkled the envelope.Search Lexmark website for user manual.Duplex printing is default.The installed link to Lexmark B2366dw Information Center leads to a Page Not Found.The SMTP error notice.

title: Tiny screen, loud, overpriced
body: This is my least favorite of several printers I've reviewed in the past couple of years. First, the good:1. Print quality is crisp, as you'd expect from a laser printer.2. Printing is fast. I don't feel like I'm hanging around, waiting for the printer to do its thing. That's after it's downloaded the data from WiFi, of course, which varies a lot by content.3. Small footprint. It really is a small machine, although it's deeper than an average bookshelf. It'll hang off the front or back, unlike other machines I've used that are wider (than deep).4. Reasonable setup. I installed from the DVD, although I suspect that wasn't necessary. It did install a very annoying pop-up "information" screen that also started appearing when I use my other Lexmark. I ended up uninstalling this, since it was useless and annoying.5. No problems with WiFi. It was set up and ready to go in a couple of minutes, and hasn't dropped or had any issues.Now the not-so-good:1. LOUD. When is was initializing, I thought it was about to take off for the moon, but it quieted down a little after that. Now it's just loud when... printing. It's easily the loudest printer I've used, so it's not a good choice if you're using it while on calls or otherwise don't want to listen to it all day.2. Tiny touchscreen. I have pretty small fingers (ladies size medium), and I had a heck of a time adding the WiFi password (for example). It's incredibly easy to fat-finger virtually everything, so using the screen is an exercise in patience and repetition (try again... try again...) That said, the touchscreen responds well.3. Flimsy build quality. The print drawer doesn't insert smoothly, and doesn't feel durable at all. All the hinges open/close slightly skewed, and take more effort than they should (and make me worry I'm going to break this thing). While flimsy printer drawers seem to be a Lexmark thing, I'd hoped they would improve on this for the new models. Nope.4. Way overpriced. The older MC series offers multi-functions at a cheaper price than this model. Since the touchscreen and print functions are the same on that series, I'm really not sure how the price of this single-function model is justified. It's just a printer. For a similar footprint and print experience, the MC series is a far better value.Recommended for: Someone who values a small footprint, doesn't mind the noise, and doesn't care about copying, faxing, or scanning, nor wants more than 1 print drawer. AND who doesn't mind paying more for this than a machine from the same company that has multi-functions in a similar footprint.Not recommended for: Everyone else

title: This one just wouldn't work...
body: The Lexmark C3426 is an attractive, reasonably compact color laser printer that at least in this one case â€“ just wouldn't work. The physical setup of the machine was simple with one sheet of illustrated instructions that was easy to follow (although the printerâ€™s control panel keys are very small and difficult to use). The printer software was also simple to install and upon completion I was rewarded with a printer test page indicating the printer was â€œcorrectly installedâ€.And then the â€œfunâ€ began. Despite a confirmed connection between computer and printer, a number of trial printing jobs resulted in â€œcommunication failureâ€ error messages. The brief version: a one-page Word file printed just fine; a one-page Excel file had long delays for a queue issue and then either failed to print or printed one-half of the page and a one-page slideshow image failed to print at all. Not being a techie, I tried some of the standard fixes for a couple of hours, but nothing worked.Finally, I reached out to Lexmark technical support. The good news is that I was connected immediately. However, after two hours on the phone with the technician â€“ during which I provided them with remote control of my computer; I moved the printer from the other room so it could be hooked up via ethernet directly to the router; and I watched patiently as they seemed to repeat clicks/commands that had already failed to work. Finally, I addressed the technician and asked what the prospects were for a resolution since we had been on the phone for two hours. I was told I probably had a wi-fi problem (despite the fact that the printer was located literally next to an Epson Workforce, with which we have no wi-fi issues) and that they were still trying to fix it. I also reminded the technician that (per the printer control panel) the printer was receiving the documents â€“ it just wasnâ€™t printing them.So, at that point I called a halt to the process and resolved to just return the printer to the box it came in. Câ€™est la vie.

title: sturdy, functional, good quality print
body: This printer was fairly easy to install and configure. The few sheets of instructions (pictograph) were a little puzzling but mainly involved steps in unpacking and untaping the unit (the outside tapes had a little folded-over bit at the end that made it easy to pull off -- no digging your thumbnail in). The installation CD is helpful but you can also download the manual from the Lexmark website, which appears to be good about product support, and the touch screen on the unit is easy to use, esp. regarding the Wifi connection. You will need to download the Lexmark printer driver, although the generic Windows driver worked well enough. The printer itself, so far, has proven fast, with fine print quality and good functionality, both for single-side printing and 2-side (duplex).Also, I've noticed no noticeable inrush, that is, the sudden electrical demand that a lot of laser printers make on startup and printing. I've had to exile some older laser printers to the other side of the house after they knock other devices off the circuit -- but not this one.Some minor quibbles: this is a straightforward color printer, with no scan or other functions. It can handle a fair range of paper sizes and weights, but is not a photo-quality printer. Unpacking the unit can be a problem, the unit is big and heavy enough, and in an outer Amazon box can be difficult to carry any distance; however, if you take the product box out you'll find handle-openings in that box, and easier to carry. You'll need a sturdy table or desk to hold the unit, and allow space not just for its footprint but a few inches around it for cooling. In all, however, a good, sturdy, functional color laser printer.

title: Set up and printing wirelessly in under 10 minutes
body: Review of: **Lexmark C3426dw Color Laser Printer**I literally unpacked this printer, set it up on its box on the floor, and was printing wirelessly from a laptop in under 10 minutes. No joke. All it required was to unpack the printer, follow the printed unpacking instructions to remove the tape and plastic protective tabs (I recommend using the printed instructions here because there were a set of shipping "tabs" in the print toner compartment that I would have missed), adding paper, and then following the manual on-screen setup prompts to get it online.I did use the WPS wifi config on my router to set this up. This is basically a simplified way to get the printer on your wireless network without even needing to enter the wifi password. I simply went through the setup on the printer, and then when it says to press the WPS button (within 120 seconds), press it (usually on the bottom of your router) and that was it. The printer was done configuring wireless. After the, a couple of steps to set the date/time/time zone, and I was done.Next, I added some paper to the tray and went into the Printer setup on my MacBook, picked the new Lexmark printer (it automatically appeared in the list of printers available), and I was done. I printed a page or two to test it, and also successfully printed from my iPhone X doing nothing more than selecting the Lexmark printer that automatically was listed as my (only) option to print (I don't have any other wireless printers online on my home network). Same story for my wife's laptop - absolutely seamless and simple setup.I have printed a few docs and other files so far, and am very impressed with the overall print quality. Sharp text, vibrant colors, and even pictures - which inexpensive laser printers are not really the best choice for printing on - look very good. And this is printing on stock office printer paper, nothing fancy. And I absolutely love having the option to print double-sided pages (duplex) without having to have the printer print on one side and then re-feed the paper into the printer upside down.Print speed is excellent, when warmed up this thing essentially prints instantly. When cold, it takes a few seconds - with a somewhat noisy fan kicking on - to get warmed up and then prints. Printing multiple pages is VERY fast for a light duty office printer. They claim 26ppm, or a page every ~2 seconds, and I have no doubt that is accurate.The only downsides I see are:-The printer is fairly heavy. The specs say about 35 pounds, but it almost feels heavier due to it's compact size.-Some of the construction feels a little cheap, in particular some of the plastic parts. When you open the toner door, you can feel a lot of flex in the plastic panel. And the plastic arms that allow the toner cartridge shelf to pull out feel very flimsy, like they would break if you pulled too hard. Nothing has actually broken yet, but some of these pieces could have been made of or reinforced with some metal.-There is no scanner. I know, this model is not sold as a MFP (multi-function printer), so I am not dinging it due to this. But keep it in mind if you need the option to use your printer as a copier.-The paper tray has to be extended out for legal size paper, making the depth of the printer a few inches more. (It took me a few minutes to figure out how this printer could accept legal size paper at all, like the product information states. The manual isn't very clear, but you need to extend the paper tray outward toward the front of the printer, and when you do this, the white plastic face plate actually sticks out further than when you are using letter size paper or smaller. If you want to print on 8.5x17 paper you have to use the manual feed slot just above the paper tray.)I cannot comment on how long the toner cartridges will last or the long term durability/reliability since I have only been using the printer for a few days. Should I discover anything in these areas that is an issue, I will update this review.From a print quality and performance, this gets a solid 5 stars for a ~$400 laser printer. I am dropping half of a one star from my overall rating due to the slight flimsiness in some of the plastic parts and the inability to handle paper larger than letter size from the print tray without making it stick out. That makes my overall rating 4.5 stars (rounding up to 5 for the Amazon review limitations).If you are looking for a solid laser print performer in a home office or small office with a small footprint, I highly recommend you consider this Lexmark C3426dw model.

title: Good printer, a little difficult to setup
body: We needed a color printer for our office and thought this would be a good choice. The small footprint is a huge plus since we have limited space. The initial setup was easy enough using my wifeâ€™s Chromebook and the printerâ€™s touchscreen. But we had to use the included CD before the Windows 10 laptops would recognize it. That slowed things down considerably.Out of the box there is a lot of tape and tags to be removed, but there is an instruction sheet with pictures to show you where to find them. There is also a cd containing an app that needed to be installed on each of our Windows laptops before they could find the printer. There were no other instructions. It some tinkering and about an hour to get all 3 Win10 laptops to print anything so some instructions would have been nice. There was a very bothersome SMTP error that wouldnâ€™t go away even once the printer was printing. I had to reboot the laptop and unplug the printer to resolve the issue.Once the setup was complete everything went smoothly. The printer works just fine printing single or double-sided pages in black and white or in color. Printing is relatively silent. The speed is good, but not great at 26 ppm. Hopefully the toner lasts as long as Lexmark claims as the biggest drawback to any printer is the cost of running it.As for quality it does a great job with text and graphics, but I wouldnâ€™t recommend it for photos. We tested it by printing our multicolor brochures that contain some colorful infographics and backgrounds. These looked quite nice and are much higher quality that the inkjet we were using. I also tried printing a couple of photos, but they were lack-luster and rather dull. My inkjet does a much better job in that regard.One note about shipping: while the Amazon box was in good condition, the printer box inside was damaged. Fortunately, the printer was not.So far so good. I have another Lexmark printer that we stopped using before the end of the first week because it couldnâ€™t print even a single page job without jamming. But this one has lasted 3 days without any jams. Hopefully this will continue.

title: My Newest Asset for Teleworking!
body: I needed an upgrade for my home printer, because I am fortunate to have a position where I can work from home during a pandemic. title: Fast black and white.  No ink drying issues like inkjet.  Wireless, USB or Ethernet
body: I do like this printer but my out of box experience was not great. I unboxed it and removed the tape from the various locations that are supposed to keep things in place during shipping. I answered a few questions on the little screen like what language do I speak and timezone, etc. Then I adjusted the paper tray to fit Letter size paper. With letter paper, the drawer hangs out of the back of the printer a little. I said to keep the paper size as letter and it said to clear a jam in the back of the printer.Well, I assumed it had to do with the paper tray since that stuck out. It was actually a piece in the door on the back of the printer that was causing the issue. Once I opened that drawer and put the piece in properly, everything went well.I got the driver from the Lexmark website. I plugged it in via ethernet and the IP address conveniently displayed on the screen. I was able to print right away.I have to say that these little printers are pretty impressive these days. I worked on laser printers and even repaired them way back in the HP 4 days. Those printers could not duplex and didn't print anywhere near as fast as these modern laser printers.I think this is a nice desk printer for someone in an office or home office. It is a great little home printer. The biggest thing for me is that it is laser and not inkjet. I have tried to use color inkjets for years. They print nice quality and the color is great. The downside is that I don't print color all that often and when I do print it is almost always black and white. (or black and white would be acceptable at least for my purposes) The ink would always dry up between uses on my inkjet printers and the ink costs more than the printer. (like razors and razor blades)It turns out that toner for this laser is quite expensive and depending on how you order it, it can be close to the price of the printer. (though the price here is very good at the moment at around $100) There are 3 different capacity toners. If you use the Lexmark return program, you save a lot of money. (you give them the empty cartridge back and you save a ton)I'm sure there will be 3rd party toner options at some point but this is what I found on the Lexmark site as far as pricing for the return program toner:Lexmark B221000 Black Return Program Toner CartridgeB221000 1200 $44.99Lexmark B221H00 Black High Yield Return Program Toner CartridgeB221H00 3,000 $79.99Lexmark B221X00 Black Extra High Yield Return Program Toner CartridgeB221X00 6,000 $159.99I only listed the price of the return program toners because the other ones are really expensive and it wouldn't make sense to buy them. (just return it and save a lot) I assume that 3rd party toners will be available at some point and may not require you to return them for a reasonable price.I have no complaints about the printer. It is somewhat compact, quiet and fast. It even prints duplex (2-sided) if you want. I love that it is WiFi capable. I had several old HP printers laying around my house that had good toner in them until fairly recently. I was basically able to print for free. They smelled bad, took up too much space and took forever to warm up.These modern, compact, desktop printers are pretty impressive. I think if you compare the cost of toner for this printer with an inkjet printer, the laser is a little less expensive on paper. In the real world, however, if you have to change your ink cartridges in your inkjet because they dried out, the laser is way less expensive.I do keep a color inkjet around for printing photos. I do not look forward to using it and going through the cleaning cycles and possibly buying ink cartridges when it has sat too long. For most of my printing, this little guy will do what I want.

title: Mac users, please set up using a printer cable!
body: Â I spent at least a half hour trying to figure out how to set up this printer to use with my Mac computer and laptop today. Visit the Lexmark website and you'll see a message that makes it appear that there isn't a driver available but then there's also something to download that will download but won't readily open with any application. I then just tried to add the printer using the "add printer" command in the system preferences but the computers could not find the printer. I was then about ready to give up when I noticed an option of connecting the printer by using a printer cable, which of course, is never supplied with any printer that you buy. I salvaged one from an old printer, attached it to my computer and the printer and the printer showed up immediately as one of my "add printer" options. Once I had added the printer, I was able to disconnect the cable and it printed flawlessly thereafter through my office's wireless network.Something that I found strange was when I tried to load up standard 8x11 copy paper. Although you wouldn't expect it, to load what I consider the standard size paper, you must extend the back of the tray from its normal configuration, which causes the back of the tray to extend out from the back of the printer, as seen in the attached picture. Why?Once I was able to get the printer up and running, I had no problems with it operating smoothly and quickly as can be seen in my video.I am using this printer as a replacement for my workhorse Brother HL-L2370DW, which still works fine but for the annoying warning about me needing to replace parts, even after they have already been replaced. Yes, I have searched online for the fix but the suggested one didn't work. You would think that if a unit is smart enough to know when it is time to replace a part, it should be smart enough to know when that part has been replaced without the owner having to go online to determine how to reset the warning indicator.

title: Really nice laser printer, but lacks instruction
body: This laser printer is great! First thing I noticed right out of the box is that it is SUPER light. I had no issues removing it from the box and carrying it over. There is a grip on the bottom of the printer so you do not have to worry about it sliding. The printer does lack instructions I feel for setting up. I looked through all the box but there are only warning and a physical setup for the device. One thing about the physical device setup is that you need to make sure to remove all the table and the covers for the toner cartridge. I would recommend that when removing the covers for the toner to do it possibly outside. The reason being is that there is a plastic tab you need to pull and remove. I honestly though I would break it pulling this plastic strip out but it does take a good amount of pull to remove. Do not worry this is something you NEED to remove to bring printing. It will carry about a small amount of toner if you are pulling on it so doing it outside will ensure you do not get toner all over your desk or carpet. Also when remove the paper cover just cut or rip it slowly and remove it. There is a part on the toner you do not want to touch. There is a drive disk if you need it but if you do not have it a simple google of the model will take you to the download page. The paper tray will have not have the paper completely pushed down and that's okay. It will be elevated in the tray. The screen just traditional black and white. There is no color or visual and the controls are fairly easy to navigate once you get use to it. The setup was a bit annoying as it loops for some reason through a lot of the setup. The printer does use a traditional computer plug to power the device and uses a type b usb cable. Be aware that the device does not come with that cable so if you want to do a direct connection you will need to purchase that separately. You can manually set up the wifi on the device itself just be aware you will have to rotate through all of the different characters. I have not had any connection issues and once on the internet network you can easily search for the printer on the network and connect to it. The printer prints super fast. It can shoot out the printout in I would say 1-2 seconds after it is done warming up. You do not have to wait very long to get the print out. It has all the indicator lights to show low on toner or low on paper. It is not a very big printer so you do not have to worry about it taking up too much space. Overall this print is a nice printer to have if you only print in black and white as well as want something that will last you a long time before replacing the toner. It also great to have for a small office as well. The only issue I have is the instructions apart from the physical setup is lacking.

title: Why do printer manufacturers assume everyone employs an IT department?
body: Printers are supposed to be patient servants who sit idle, but snap to attention when you need them. They do seem too if you have a wired connection. Adding Wifi seems to reduce the printer's IQ by half. Unless you have your own IT department or a 12 year old close by to rescue you. Now that that's out of the way, here are my impressions of this Lexmark B3340 so far. I was looking for a replacement for my Cannon, that was most of all intuitive and whose Wifi just plain worked every time. Unboxing seemed promising but suspect since documentation included one sheet of printed media and a DVD. The single sheet of "instructions" contained no words, just a few cave wall drawings with a helpful bent page indicator in the lower right hand corner indicating the need to turn the page over to continue. Good thing, I never would have noticed it was printed on both sides! Step 12 indicates you need to turn the printer on. The final step indicates you insert the DVD into your laptop. If only laptops still had DVD readers. In my Apple world those are barely even remembered. So there we both sat in awkward silence.There is a tiny, single line display so I decided to break the ice and start pushing the few buttons there. It asked if I wanted to set it up using an app. Yes please. I downloaded the only Lexmark app I could find onto my phone, but that proved to be a dead end. I used my iMac to try to locate drivers for the B3340 and finally wading through microscopic online print and charts seemed to find what I needed so clicked the hyperlink for Mac. Nothing downloaded. I connected the printer to my desktop to see if that might make a love connection. I thankfully had the correct cable. Would have been nice if Lexmark had included one but maybe no one does that any more. Though others seem to make even a tiny effort to give you a modicum of direction. I opened my Printer preference tab, and by golly, it had recognized the new printer. Clicking on some options seemed promising but still no directions. I went back to that single line display and started clicking through and eventually found an option to connect to Wifi. It found my network thankfully and asked for my password. I hoped there might be a more handy input method. But no, you need to go through small a, capital A, small b capital B, etc. for each part of your password. Mine dutifully is 10 characters long so it was a lot of tapping. Eventually all was set up, and I directed the computer to print a page and selected the Lexmark. Thankfully it instantly printed the page, though the quality seemed a little light and non-crisp. Imagining there were internal adjustments I went back to single line display, but nothing there. In the mean time the printer went into sleep mode. I opened the Printer choices but nothing helpful there. After pushing the back arrow on the printer it said it was "ready" and fully awake. Thats when, in the Printer section under the "general" tab, there was a tiny box that said it would take you to the printer web site. I bit, and although it's not obvious at all, there are nests of settings that will adjust your printer, including print quality and darkness level. I made the adjustments, printed another page and the page was beautiful. I was interrupted but returned to make sure all was in order, tried to print another page but nothing. It said it couldn't find the printer. Ten minutes later, the page printed.Over all, this seems to be a solid relatively compact printer. It says it's made out of steel though the exterior seems like hard plastic. The single line of display gives basic information only after lots of clicking and little intuitive guidance. Once all is set up to the settings of your choice, it seems promising. I cancelled sleep mode but it still seems to doze off and not print wirelessly on command. I'll keep tinkering. In conclusion, unit build seems solid, compact and unencumbered by buttons and blinking lights. Five stars there. As for helpful setup directions or any guidance I would give it zero stars if possible. I believe this will prove to be a solid, reliable printer. As long as I don't need to wake it up by physically pushing a button on the controls, and the wifi proves reliable, I should be happy. If you're reading Lexmark, can't you simply include a second piece of printed instructions that gives a buyer even a scrap of guidance? At least for customers who exist in the Apple universe, or with Windows laptops that lack DVD access?

title: Great monochrome laser for the home/small office
body: This is a compact, somewhat lightweight black & white laser printer. No scanner, fax, or copier. But as a printer it is excellent. Print speeds are fast at just about 1.5 seconds per page and the built-in duplexer is great. The instructions are just pictures, which can be a bit confusing, but once you have the printer out of the box they make more sense. This only comes with a power cable so if you're going to connect directly to a computer you will need a printer cable (that funky cable with a squarish connector). Because of all our devices we went with the wireless option for connectivity. The 2-line monochrome screen is used to set it up (date, time, time zone, connect to network). Again, no instructions. If you've set up a printer before this is not terrible, but a user manual would have made it much better. Do note that your network has to be 2G and not 5G. It does come with a CD but I prefer to download the latest from the manufacturer's website. This is a 100MB download for the full package. The Lexmark app installed fine on my Android tablet (Samsung) and I was able to print from there as well. This is a simple but very nice B&W laser that works well for any home office or even a small business office.

title: Great Desktop Laser Printer!

title: Great Printer
body: Great printer, easy to set up, prints on both sides.. I was able to set this up to print my chest since my old printer was malfunctioning. Very happy with product.

title: Incredibly fast printing, clean black and white pages, easy setup
body: I love this laser printer from Lexmark. It prints incredibly fast and the pages are perfect. Blacks are smooth and dark while the white page is clean and smudge free. Setup was almost a breeze. I did have trouble connecting to wifi but it eventually worked out. The printer does make a little grunt after each round of printing, but I'm assuming that's normal. I removed the drum and reseated it a few times without any difference in this response. Otherwise, everything works well.Ignore other reviews that say this printer can hold an extra large toner that prints 6000 pages. I used to set my inkjet to print in grayscale only because the ink is expensive and I don't print photos or need color for personal use. My inkjet is now in the closet. I'm pleased with the performance of this printer and would recommend it to my own family and friends.

username: Leah Maines, best-selling, award-winning author, actor, and editor

title: Disposable
body: I didn't do my research before ordering this printer. In this day and age, I didn't really think that I would have to because usually you can find aftermarket toner cartridges on the cheap, but I'm having trouble finding toner cartridges for the Lexmark B2338adw Monochrome Laser Printer other than the $87 Lexmark return cartridge here on Amazon.If you do the math, that means that the printer is worth about $20 and the toner is worth $90! To be fair, the starter toner is a specially loaded toner cartridge with far less toner than the regular one, so it could be argued that the printer is $50 - maybe. But if you think about it, you could easily make a case for just ordering a new printer every time the toner runs out, rather than using the same printer and ordering new toner each time.I feel like this is deceiving. It would be far more honest to sell the printer with a REAL CARTRIDGE that is loaded full and charge the full price - that way you would know what it was going to cost you in real world dollars and perhaps more importantly, you could comparison shop and see what it actually costs compared to other printers. The REAL price of this printer is the price of the printer PLUS a toner cartridge which is closer to $200 than $100.Otherwise, this looks like a decent laser printer that will handle heavy printing loads and is easy to set up with Windows or Mac. But I am so put off by the marketing and price of the cartridges that I don't know if I trust the company with my business.Before you school me on the fact that all printer companies do this, I am aware that it is a common practice - but I have never seen it quite so blatant or so costly. Usually you can bypass the printer company's overpriced toner or ink and save money. But for whatever reason, there appear to be no choices except Lexmark's expensive toner. I'd shop around and find a printer that isn't going to cost quite so much in consumables as time goes on.

title: Perfect for home use and multiple options for printing wirelessly
body: This Lexmark B2338adw Print Only Monochrome Laser Printer is perfect for home use and has multiple options for printing from your computer, your phone or your tablet.Understand that this is a laser printer. Laser printers print very differently from ink jet printers. It uses powdered toner which is attracts to the paper via an electric charge. A fuser permanently fuses the toner to the paper. Hence, there are no print heads or liquid ink. This process makes a laser printer and attractive choice for people who do not print large amounts or frequently as there are no print heads to get clogged or ink to dry up.Although there are color laser printers, this is a monochrome printer so only one toner cartridge, which is easy to install and replace and all of the toner is available for use as laser printers don't need priming, as ink jet printers do. Laser printers also produce incredibly crisp prints.One thing to note is that the toner cartridge for this printer is currently ~$90. Before you gasp, realize that the toner cartridge is rated for about 3,000 pages. There is a greater initial outlay for a laser printer toner cartridge but you don't generally replace them as often as ink jet cartridges. This printer comes with a starter toner cartridge installed, which is rated for about 1,500 pages.You can use this printer directly connected to your computer via a USB printer cable (NOT included), over your wifi network or as a wired network printer via an ethernet cable (NOT included.) Lexmark has a free app called the Lexmark Mobile Assistant to help you set the printer up. I have an android phone and I downloaded the app but for some reason, it couldn't find the printer. I didn't try for long because you can actually set it up using the control panel on the printer. You just need to know the name of your wifi network and the password. The printer connected instantly to my wifi network.Next, I tried installing the software on the included CD but again, ran into some issues with the software not finding the printer. I skipped that and went into my Windows Control Panel, selected Hardware and Sound, and then selected Advanced Printer Setup. It found the printer and when I selected it, Windows automatically installed the drivers for the printer and prompted me to print a test page to ensure it was working properly. The test page printed instantly and perfectly.If you have a Chromebook, you won't be able to connect the printer to your computer via a USB printer cable. Instead, you will use Google Cloud Print, which you will need to set up. You can also print wirelessly via Apple AirPrint, Mopris Print Service and Lexmark Mobile Print so you have a lot of options for printing from your phone or tablet.This is a printer only. It doesn't scan or copy as it is not an all-in-one printer. It does, however, have auto duplexing, which is automatic, double sided printing. It has a 250 sheet paper tray and a multi-purpose feeder for envelopes and specialty papers. It prints very quickly - even double sided pages. Print quality is excellent.My only complaint is that, like many printers these days, there is no printed user manual included. You can download it from the Lexmark website, though. While you are there, note that there is a firmware update available for this printer. You'll need to download the update and follow the directions carefully to install the update. Firmware updates are important and shouldn't be ignored so take time to do this.

title: High quality printer with full AirPrint support for the Mac and iPhone
body: This is an excellent printer for Mac users, especially if you have in iPhone. There is a two page cartoon showing how to unpack it, and the only confusing thing is that there is both a toner cartridge and an imaging unit into which the toner cartridge fits. When the printer arrives, both items are installed but with packing tape and pads surrounding them and they must be removed. The cartoons are not all that helpful in figuring out what to remove, but it is fairly obvious when you have the item in your hand. Just make sure all the tape and foam padding are removed and replace the imaging unit first, and then put the toner cartridge in next.The software setup is trivial if you have an iPhone. Download the Lexmark Mobile Print app from the app store and follow the prompts. I was done in less than a minute and the printer was then available via air print on all the other mac computers and phones in the house. The WIFI on this printer is highly stable.The reason I gave this only four stars is that Lexmark charges too much for its toner cartridges. Indeed, the toner cartridge for this printer costs more than the printer! Furthermore, the printer comes with a starter toner cartridge that will only last a few months at most. So my strong recommendation is to buy the printer + toner package. It will save you about $20.That complaint noted, this is an outstanding and reliable printer. For mac users it is especially nice because AirPrint has been fully implemented, which is not the case for many printers I have bought which claim to support it, but have only a partial implementation.

title: Lexmark B2338 Print Only Monochrome Duplex Laser Printer
body: I switched to laser printers because I rarely print in color or make copies and the constant expense of color cartridges that were little used but dried-out anyway seemed a wasteful use of limited resources. This printer has a USB and an Ethernet port so it can be connected wirelessly or through a wired network or a computer.The printer creates crisp clean output and preferences regarding resolution, darkness, brightness, etc. can be selected by the user. This device arrives with a toner cartridge that is stated to print 1500 copies which is half the regular cartridge (B231000) capacity of 3000 copies. If interested, there is also a high-yield cartridge available.Printing can be accomplished through any device connected to the printerâ€™s network. To use a mobile device, like a smartphone or tablet, the Lexmark Print app must be loaded. In Windows 10 no app is neededâ€“ just set up like any other printer. Details of my experience configuring the printer follow but in summary so far the printer is fast, the print quality is excellent and it works reliably whether printing from my wireless phone and laptop as well as my wired desktop PC.Following the two page visual instructions included in the box, I unpacked the printer and plugged in the power cord. The 2 by 1/2 inch illuminated display window statedâ€”setup using the mobile app. At the Apple app store I installed the Lexmark Mobile Assistant.The app instructed I should go to Settings on iPhone, find printer name shown on the printer display and connect to my local WiFi network using my network passphrase. Then I returned to the app and followed the remaining steps. If not planning to connect to WiFi, connect to a wired network using the Ethernet port or connect directly with a USB cable. These cables are not included.At this point it is ready to print wirelessly. On my desktop the printer was immediately recognized by Windows 10 so I did not load the included software disc. As mentioned above to print with my smartphone I loaded the Lexmark Print app. Once the mobile app is loaded the printer appears in the Sharing option for all apps that support printing.No printed manual is included but PDFs for a Quick Start Guide along with a very detailed User Manual are available at the company website along with information about firmware updates, FAQs, etc.If security is a concern a Pin number can be established. In the configuration settings a pin number may be created that applies to all jobs or individually at print time. In either case there is no output until the user types in the pin number at the printer console. Printing can be restricted to network users and/or local accounts.Also the user can erase (sanitize) printer memory (automatically saved image) to avoid sensitive documents being reprinted without authorization. This is a complex feature detailed in the user manual. Decent features at this price point.

title: Good quality printing
body: I received this printer to review as part of the Amazon Vine program. Below are my pros/cons.Pros:- Very good quality printing (easily better than my old inkjet printer).- Prints pages quickly; when printing single-sided, this baby can really spit the printed pages out.- Comes with duplex included (both-sided printing).- It's smooth; it doesn't shake "back-and-forth" like my old ink-jet printer did when printing.- Seems designed to be largely idiot-proof, and I'm the idiot testing it.Cons:- Instructions were a single sheet with several large diagrams; I followed the items and was able to get the printer up and running. NOTE - install the printer drivers using the supplied disk, not by searching the internet. Also note that you do have an option to download stuff to your cell phone, but I'm old school and prefer to have an instruction manual included and in front of me.- The printer did not print "duplex" right out of the box. Here is where the lack of a printed manual with a "troubleshooting" section was sorely felt. I had to go online, where I found a solution: "confirm that the paper type selected on your printer corresponds to the media actually loaded into the printer. Do this through the printer driver (Paper tab) as well as the printer operator panel (Paper Menu). IMPORTANT: Labels and transparencies will print on one side of the page only (simplex) regardless of the printer or driver settings. If the media type is set to Labels or Transparency, change the setting to allow for duplex printing."- The printer jammed a lot and often grabbed more than one sheet of paper. I'm hoping this will lessen, as I get used to this printer's idiosyncrasies.Things worth noting (neither a pro nor a con):- This is advertised as a single function printer, and it is ... single function means no copying or scanning ... all it does is print. Read the manufacturer provided info carefully.- While the printer isn't overly large, it is heavy ... around 50 pounds.- It has a paper cassette tray, and there is a slot where you can feed letters, envelopes, and transparencies in manually.Overall, I like this printer, and am looking forward to getting a lot of use out of it. If you can afford it, the time to shift to color laser printers has arrived. Four stars.

title: Incredibly frustrating setup, but good print quality. No network security.
body: I'm rating this based on how it works as a printer, not according to the incredibly frustrating setup. If I'm rating the installation experience, I'd have given it at most 2 stars - and only because I managed to figure it out in the end through experimentation and trial and error.Instead of describing my arduous installation experience, I'm just going to give a list of tips of what you should do.1. I wanted to use this over WiFi. If you can use it over wired Ethernet, it might be much simpler.2. I tried to configure it with the front panel. If you have a long WiFi password, please reconsider. I entered it anyway, taking 5 minutes to enter it, and it wouldn't connect to my WiFi.3. I'm using an Android phone. The Lexmark Mobile Assistant only configures the WiFi settings. It will ask you to connect to the printer's WiFi through Settings.4. If you see a warning message on Android saying there's no Internet connection after you're connected to it, and to tap on it for options, TAP ON IT FOR OPTIONS. Accept that it has no Internet connection. I didn't do that, and as a result, the Mobile Assistant would not go on to the next step.5. After you've configured WiFi, the printer may kick you back to pick language, and ask if you want to use Mobile Assistant for setup again. If it does that, reply NO. Then, when it comes to the screen where it asks you if you want to configure WiFi, say NO. It will then say "Connected".Getting to step 5 above took me 2 hours of trial and error and multiple restarts.6. Check to see if you need a firmware update. Lexmark's website has a good description of how to update firmware. The C2325dw does not have a USB A port at the back, so you need to do either FTP or through the internal web server.7. The web server is a much more user friendly procedure, but it wouldn't complete for me. The printer showed a CRC error after 45%, and eventually rebooted. If it works for you, skip step 8.8. I updated it with Windows FTP client. If Windows prompt you to give it firewall permission, grant it. The instructions did not tell you to first put the client in binary transfer mode. So instead of just "PUT <filename>", I first issued "BIN", then "HASH" (optional, to show hash marks as it's uploading so that I know it's still transferring) then finally "PUT <filename>". This worked. Printer rebooted and showed new firmware.9. To install Windows drivers, I just downloaded and ran "Lexmark Printer Software G2 Driver and Software". I ignored "Lexmark Printer Software G2 Postscript Driver Package" since the first one is much larger and includes Postscript support.10. Running it the first time, it couldn't detect the printer, and became unresponsive. I killed the task, then ran it again. Second time it detected the printer immediately.I hope the above was helpful. Maybe printers with newer versions of firmware (mine was 050 something) will be more stable.The printer itself is very heavy. I didn't weigh it, but Lexmark says it weighs 45 lbs and that seems about right. Unpacking it, you need to open up 2 compartments and pull out some straps that stabilize the internal parts during shipping before plugging it in. It looks a bit simple, and the plastic walls seem a bit thin, but frankly it's quite amazing for a color laser printer that costs under $300.The back of the printer has a USB Type B and Ethernet port. No USB or Ethernet cables are supplied so if you want to use one of these ports, you need to provide your own cable. USB Type B is the one with a large-ish square connector typically only used in printers.There's a paper tray and you can adjust it for different paper size. Mine was set just a little too small for Letter, so I was a bit puzzled when I put paper in and it didn't quite fit. Adjusting it is pretty straightforward.Configuring it through the two line LCD is quite tedious. It's much easier doing it through the web interface. One thing that concerns me is that neither the web interface nor the FTP interface has any security, and it's not obvious to me if there's any way to add even a simple password to protect it. Make sure the network you're connecting it to is secure, and it's a good idea to turn it off when you're done printing.Once everything is set up, printing it is very straightforward. I haven't printed many pages through it yet, but so far printing is smooth and fast, and print quality is good. Text is crisp and I look forward to not having to pay for expensive ink cartridges. I'm not sure why the magenta toner shows as 2/3 full before I printed a single page though (see photo).I will keep this review updated based on my experience. I thought I'd get this out first so that the installation tips can help some people.

title: The Lexmark 3340dw is a fast, no frills laser printer that won't break the bank.
body: As I write this, we are still very much in the midst of the Covid-19 pandemic, and I suspect that will still be the case come November. Here in The Buckeye State we have to request an absentee ballot by sending an application via USPS. Since I do not intend to go to the polls in person, I chose to replace my worthless, broken, 6 year old Canon inkjet printer so that I could print out the ballot application. The old inkjet actually stopped functioning properly a few years ago, and I had limped along during that time relying on the printers at work for all of my printing needs. However, I am now working from home for the foreseeable future and do not want to don a mask and drive into the office just to pick up a piece of paper.My only requirement: I was determined to have a laser printer. I've had a string of inkjets that all did a number of things, like make copies or scan documents. All of them were doomed to be mediocre at best at any task assigned to them, but the clincher is that they always stopped working after about 3 or 4 years. What's more, they are incredibly slow. The Canon for instance liked to spend about 2 full minutes making a bunch of noises, gears turning, beeps beeping, lights flashing, and that was before it even pulled a sheet of paper out of the tray. Once it finally started printing, it was like watching a JPEG download on dial-up. All that is to say that inkjets suck, and the old Canon has a date with my trusty metal bar a la the dreaded fax machine in the movie Office Space.This printer fit the bill for me. The bulk of my printing needs are things like the aforementioned ballot application, or airline boarding passes. For that reason, I don't really see a need for color unless you are doing graphics or photos. I also have a phone with an excellent camera. It can capably scan a document into PDF form, and I can print that PDF to my hearts content on my new laser printer. For that reason, I also saw no need to have a copier or scanner attached to my printer. This printer does the one thing I need it to do, and it does it fast. How fast, you ask? There is a span of about 1.5 seconds between hitting the print button and retrieving a completed printout from the printer. Perhaps this is average performance for a laser printer? Eh, what do I know? I mainly bought it because it had 5 star reviews and was pretty much the cheapest option.As for installation, I would recommend going to the Lexmark site first and downloading the documentation. The one page installation guide that comes in the box is clearly meant for an international audience (think IKEA), due to it being a series of slightly confusing pictographs that lacked any meaningful text instructions. If you want to print from any computer running windows 10 then you will want to go to the Lexmark site again, and download and install the driver first, presuming of course that you do not have a cd-rom drive to use the included install disk (it is 2020 after all). I tried installing without the installation software on my windows 10 desktop, and it inverted the color so that it printed a black background with white text. Obviously that will use up your toner in a hurry. My Macs on the other hand worked perfectly with AirPrint. Also, get the mobile app to set it up. The on-device interface is where I suspect they cut corners to get the price so low, and the app is faster and easier by far. Once you've done that, you can administer the printer settings via it's web server on a browser, which has no such shortcomings as the on-device interface. Last recommendation, setup security so your wannabe hacker neighbors don't decide to do it for you, and lock you out of your own printer.This printer is my first Lexmark, and it has exceeding my expectations so far. I would definitely recommend it to anyone with a similar use case to mine. However the jury is still out on the longevity of the device, due to a lack of a sufficient amount of time passing or an ability to divine the future, but I'll keep my fingers crossed.

title: Buy something else
body: The final edit of how I feel about this printer.BUY SOMETHING ELSE!The printer is barely OK but the toner cartridges, at about $100 each for each color, are phenomenally expensive. So far I can't find anybody to supply re-manufactured or some other kind of alternate.Everything below this line is my first impression.The pro.I set the printer up connected directly to my computer via USB so I can't comment on other setups. The USB setup was simple, just install the CD and run it.The tiny screen on the printer is adequate for the job.The con.The print quality is a puzzle.I unboxed and removed all the shipping tape and printed a few pages. I was very disappointed and thought I'd have to send the printer back. The problem was the density of the print was very inconsistent with some very light places and some almost ok. It was late and I figured I'd try a few more pages the next day and see if there were some print quality adjustments I could make. I didn't get to the printer until late the next day and, without doing anything, printed a few pages, some just black text and some schematics that contained a few colors. Those prints were very good. So, the puzzle is what changed that allowed the printer to work properly?One other thing is the envelope printing is a little off, at least using Word (2016). When the envelope is printed part of the return address doesn't get printed because it's off the envelope. Moving the address about a half inch in the envelope set-up corrects the problem, but the correction doesn't persist so it needs to be set every time. There may be a more elegant fix, I have to play with it.My conclusion, now that the print quality has gotten better, is I'm pleased with the purchase.Update:When you print a document that is only black the print is lousy. If the page has any color on it the black print, and the color print, is very good.One more update then I'm done:I went to the printer settings and changed the quality/toner darkness from the default "Use Printer Settings" to "Use Toner Darkness" and printed a page. Actually, I printed 7 pages of all black text. The problem went away. Then, I switched back to the original "Use Printer Settings" and printed the same 7 pages again. The problem seems to have gone away with this setting too. My guess is the printer had to calibrate itself.Last but not least, there's a software update I may install. The version that came with the printer is pretty old.

title: Great for home office use I would not suggest using this for business
body: So firstly I want to start off by saying there are a lot of negative reviews on this that are literally unjustified. These are usually problems with the toner cartridge or people fail to properly follow the directions on initial setup. In addition I can vouch that the Wi-Fi on this does work flawlessly with almost every device I've used it on I have yet to test it with Alexa but we'll be doing so after I write a skill set for it. I have enclosed a bunch of photos a picture of the Disney Castle is printed on Plain paper and the other image was printed on photo paper So now onto my review...So in this review I'm going to address three areas the printer quality, the print quality, and the cost of use. First let's start with the overall quality this seems to be like every other laser printer as far as the overall housing internal components seem to be primarily plastic which is normal 4 most printers in its class. It does not come with a USB plug although one can be purchased. It does come with a power cord. The toner tray slides out from the front and the clips that lock the toner in place are made out of plastic so over a long. Of time they could present a problem and possibly break off. I would not say this is a deal-breaker. Does printer stands 9 in tall and is 16 in wide and is approximately 15 and 1/2 in deep. It contains built in Wi-Fi and has a port for ethernet. This has a port for USB but does not contain the USB cord itself. In addition does does have a manual feeder tray which is located in the front and it also has the automatic sheet feed tray which is just under it . You can print small photographs using 4 x 6 in Premium Photo Paper . But I have not tried anything smaller than this as far as paper is concerned . Envelope printing is also excellent and will leave absolutely zero creases in the envelope compared to most other Laser Printers. This comes with for starter toner cartridges which come already in the printer. You must follow the setup directions very closely to avoid damaging the product. This does come with a CD with drivers and software. Now moving on to the print quality compared to some of the competitors this print quality is actually really decent when compared to Samsung HP and brother Laser Printers in its class.. this printer that I received had very limited instructions which I was kind of surprised at. Especially for Lexmark. In my eyes this look like a factory recert where they had printed documentation off of a printer and enclosed it. But none the less was very easy to set up and all of the user manuals and Owner Manuals can be downloaded directly from Lexmark website. Moving on to the value I only gave this three stars for a couple of reasons first the product as compared to others of its class is very cheap I think I paid approximately $140 for this whereas most printers in this class range about $200 or more so that in itself is a great deal moving on to the second reason after doing an ample amount of research I have found that the toner cartridges are quite expensive to replace. For a refill directly from Lexmark it cost approximately $70 per cartridge. Other sites I have found the refill toner cartridges to be anywhere from $200 per set, up to literally almost $400 for the set of cartridges. in addition to this if you have the knowledge to do so you can purchase a toner refill kit. I have found the cheapest price to be approximately $70 this includes all four colors however the caveat is there is no toner reset chip available at this time. Although several reviews for toner refill on this specific printer have all said that it will let you print even after the chip is considered depleted I feel you must research it yourself once the toner chips are made available they are very easy to replace and you could reuse your toner cartridges for a long time. On that note I would say for a general home office printer this is a very good purchase if you are planning on purchasing this for business use I would suggest not going with this printer and going with a brother as the toner cartridges and chips are much cheaper and they have been in business far longer than Lexmark and their parts are made with much higher quality with businesses in mind.

title: Problems After One Year - Will Be Discontinued in 2020
body: I purchased the MX417DE on May 3, 2018. It worked great. I work from home as an Adjunct Professor. I am also a doctoral student. I print a lot. My in-box toner lasted for approximately 8 months. I purchased another toner in January, 2019. Last week (the week of July 8th), my printer began to print faded pages as if the toner was low. However, the diagnostics indicated that I had 80% toner remaining. I contacted Lexmark. They indicated it was a Toner problem. So, I purchased a new toner directly from Lexmark for $240.00. The toner was not the problem. So, they indicated it was the Transfer Roller. I purchased that for $25+. That was not the problem. Since my Lexmark warranty was expired, I contacted Square Trade (An Allstate Company) who held my extended warranty. They determined it was a hardware problem (after one year of having the printer). They offered me a cash-out or a replacement printer. I chose the cash out (5 to 7 business days). I contacted Lexmark to order a replacement. I was informed that if I contacted presales, I could get 30% off a new printer to help mitigate some of the cost because the cost of the printer had gone up since I purchased it. title: Very capable office printer!
body: The Lexmark MB2442adwe is a great choice for a small office or a workgroup. It is a monochrome printer, so it might not be the best choice for a home printer. However, if you are satisfied that you don't need/want to print color at home, it would make a great home machine too. It feels very sturdy and well-made.This all-in-one prints at up to 42ppm, and is rated for a monthly print volume of up to 10,000 pages, so it should be up to the demands of most small offices. In testing, it reached (or at least came pretty close) to the 42ppm. I had no desire to burn through 20 or so reams of paper though, so I can't vouch for the monthly volume rating. Print quality was outstanding and it presented no problems using AirPrint from an iPhone or iPad. Setup was a breeze (with Macs, anyway; we don't have any Windows PCs), both wireless and using Ethernet. The instructions are clear and relatively concise. The MB2442adwe prints its first page quickly, too, usually spitting out the first page 7-8 seconds after hitting, "print."It has a couple of features that are very helpful in an office environment. The first is the ability to print securely. If you select this option in the print job dialog, your job won't print until you go to the printer and enter a PIN you selected when printing. This is very useful to ensure that sensivive documents don't print until you are physically at the printer waiting for them. The second is the ability to add an additional, 550-page capacity, input tray. The built-in tray holds 250 sheets, plus there is the usual multi-purpose feeder (which in the MB2442adwe holds 100 pages, more than these typically can handle). The addition of an extra input tray can either give you access to an additional paper size/type, or just add extra capacity of a single size so you don't have to refill as often.There are a couple of things that are less than optimal, however. The first is this cryptic note in the "Specs" section on the Lexmark website: "Product functions only with replacement cartridges designed for use in a specific geographical region." This appears to mean that replacement cartridges are locked to a specific region, sort of like DVDs; I've personally never heard of this and am just speculating. That may or may not be an issue, but is something you should be aware of.The second is that, while the printer is well-suited for a moderate to heavy burden of office printing, the scanner and copier are not if you are scanning or copying duplex documents. It scans duplex, to be sure. However, it does this by way of RADF (Reversing Automatic Document Feeder). This means that it scans one side of the page, ejects that page not quite all the way, then re-feeds it to scan the other side. Essentially, it takes twice as long to scan a 2-sided document as it does a single-sided one. The ideal scanners and copiers have true Duplex Automatic Document Feeders (DADF), with two scanning elements so that both sides of the page are scanned during a single pass. This is not an issue unless you have a heavy scanning or copying volume, AND a great percentage of that volume consists of documents printed on both sides. The ADF holds 50 pages, more than most printers intended for home use, which is consistent with its office-focused design.The price of this printer is quite reasonable for the quality and capacity you get in the printing area, so it stands to reason money would have to be saved somewhere, and it was in the scanning/copying functions. That being said, the scanner is plenty fast, so you may very well find this to be a non-issue. However, it is something else you should be aware of.The all-in-one also sends and receives faxes, but I don't have a landline, so I couldn't test either.Overall, this is a great printer, especially for the price. I would have no hesitation to use it in my office.

If you select this option in the print job dialog, your job won't print until you go to the printer and enter a PIN you selected when printing. This is very useful to ensure that sensivive documents don't print until you are physically at the printer waiting for them. The MB2338adw does not have this ability. There seems to be a reference to it in the manual, but I think that is a mistake.The MB2338adw does have the ability to add an additional, 550-page capacity, input tray. title: Lexmark MX317 printer copier scanner - good machine but mediocre instructions
body: Copier and printer seem very good; instructions are chaotic. I haven't tried scanning photos yet. Here's the good, the bad and the ugly. The copier (fairly large...more like an office printer) came with a one page (front & back) photo/symbol instruction sheet with no verbiage. I discovered 2 slightly different user guides on the web...the major difference being the connector panel configuration in the rear. Using and de-cyphering the no language, symbols only sheet, I removed all the tape (way more than the four shown on the sheet) and removed the 2 cartridges, rotated them 3X and then reinserted. I was accustomed to pulling a plastic film/tab on other cartridges; Lexmark doesn't use them but they did have a complex plastic harness on one, for want of a better description. The single, non verbiage sheet then clearly shows NOT CONNECTING the MX317 to the computer....this is INCORRECT; I assume the sheet is referring to Lexmark's other model, which is wireless and more expensive. You will need to purchase a USB (a) to USB (b) cable (search Amazon "USB to printer cable") and connect the printer to the PC. The instructions show connecting the printer cable (to a router) which won't work since this is the (cheaper) printer connected to a PC model; then the sheet instructs you to turn the printer on (step 14) and lastly inserting the enclosed CD (step 15). I assumed the CD loaded the print driver; which it does,.....BUT...it also contains the step by step instructions (30+ pages or so) in English so....INSERT the disk FIRST and follow these CD instructions...which contradict the single page hieroglyphics sheet. The CD instructs the user to NOT connect the printer cable until the last step. So...to summarize...insert the disk into your PC and follow or print out the CD's instructions. ignore the single sheet hieroglyphics unless you can't read English ..unpack and set up the printer/copier....connect the printer to your PC using a USB to printer ("A" to "B" USB) cable which you must purchase, and follow the setup/programming instructions on the CD disk.... You will also have to program the copier/printer using its "console" buttons (select language, time zone, functionality....FTP = file transfer protocol which I don't recommend: if you choose FAX...you'll need to input (and have connected) a land line telephone number. Hope this commentary helps. As the other reviewers have noted, this copier/printer is a bargain unless you are wanting a wireless printer...but even that will still require two cables.

title: The carts themselves feel like they are 1/4 full
body: This printer is a huge scam. This printer uses a cartridge that is the same shape and size as the toner cartridges for the mx310. Exact same shape and size. My company at one time purchased 8 mx310 printers and I purchased the toner for them. I never bought the toner directly from lexmark or the lexmark branded toner because the toner cartridges were like $300. You could get them much cheaper from companies that refill them and pay about $80. Now none of those companies that refill them can refill the cartridges for the mx317 for some reason. The lexmark branded cartridges for the mx317 are exactly the same shape and size as the ones for the mx310 but they fill the cartridges up maybe 33% of the way. the toner carts only last 2500 pages. Most other laserjet printers and their toner cartridges will print anywhere from 5000 to 10000 for roughly $80 to $150. That is an acceptable price per print. These printers work with cartridges that only do 2500 prints and the carts cost $75-100. That is unacceptable. The carts themselves feel like they are 1/4 full. I have been ordering toner for roughly 10 different printers for the past 5 years. I know the weight and feel of every one of these carts. The carts for this mx317dn are the exact same size and shape as the 50F1X00 and yet the 50F1X00 will do 10,000 prints and this cart is rated for 2500? that is BS.
